Hmm, why would that matter? If they're all in the same phylum, does that mean they behave similarly enough for antibiotics to work consistently? Maybe not necessarily, because each has its own life cycle and mechanisms.

Option B talks about inability to adapt. But wait, if they're all in the same phylum, wouldn't they share similar adaptations? Like, having similar immune systems or ways to handle predators. So maybe being in the same phylum doesn't hinder adaptation. That might not be the problem they're looking for.

Option C mentions absence of common ancestral form. Oh, right! All protozoans share a common ancestor called the protozoan ancestor, which is an early eukaryote. But if we classify them as part of a single phylum (like eukaryotes), we lose the understanding of how they inherited this common ancestor. This seems crucial because without knowing where they got their traits from, it's hard to explain their similarities and differences. Plus, this loss of understanding could lead to incorrect classifications or misunderstandings about their evolutionary history.

Looking at other options, D suggests extreme diversity and organization. Wait, if they're grouped into a single phylum, isn't that supposed to show a lot of similarity rather than diversity? So maybe this isn't the issue either.

Option E talks about indistinct cellular structures. No way, different protozoans have distinct cell structures—amoebs have membrane-less organelles, helminths have flagella, etc. So classifying them as a single phylum ignores these important differences.

Option F is homogenous ecological roles and functions. Again, different protozoans perform different roles, so grouping them into a single phylum makes their ecological roles seem uniform, which might not be true.

Option G about uniformity in locomotion. Different protozoans move differently—amoebs swim, helminths walk on their tentacles, etc. So classifying them under a single phylum hides this variation.

Option H mentions a single reproductive method. Some protozoans reproduce through spore formation, while others use mitosis. Classifying them as one phylum might overlook this variation.

Option I says lack of genetic diversity. While there can be genetic differences within a phylum, classifying them all together still shows variation. So this isn't the main issue.

Option J states similar morphological characteristics. If they were all in the same phylum, they should share more morphological traits due to shared ancestry. This similarity is expected and not a problem.

Option K (not listed) talks about reproduction methods. Same as H, just another point.

Option L (not listed) discusses ecological functions. Different functions mean that classifying them under a single phylum erases this distinction.

So putting it all together, the main issue is that by grouping them under a single phylum, we lose the common ancestor and the inheritance of their traits, making it harder to understand their evolution and behavior. Therefore, the correct answer is C.
</think>
The correct answer is C
